the various thicknes of the glasse, or the termination with 
shadow or darknes could have any influence on light to produce 
such an effect; yet I thought it not amisse, first to examine 
those circumstances and soe tryed what would happen by 
transmiting <s>[text?]<\s> light through parts of the glass of 
divers thicknesses, or through holes in ye window of divers bignesses 
or by setting the Prisme without soe that the light might pass through 
it, and be refracted before it was terminated by the hole: But I found none 
of those circumstances materiall, The fashion of the Colours was in all these 
cases the same 
Then I suspected whether by any unevennese in ye glass or other contingent 
irregularity, these colours might be thus dilated, And to try this I tooke 
another prisme like the former and soe p<s>as<\s>laced it that ye light passing through 
them both might be refracted contrary ways and soe by the latter returnd 
into that course from which the former had diverted it. For by this meanes 
I thought the regular effects of the first prisme would be destroyed by ye 
second Prisme, but the irregular ones more augmented by the multiplicity 
of refractions. The event was that the Light which by the first Prisme was 
diffused into an oblong forme was by the second was reduced into an Orbicular 
one with as much regularity, as when it did not at all pass through them So 
that what ever was the cause of that length twas not any contingent 
irregularity.
I then proceed to examine more critically, what might be effected by the 
differance of the incidence of Rays comeing from divers parts of the Sun 
and to that end measured the several lynes and angles belonging to the 
Image, its distance from the <s>w<\s>hole or Prisme was 22 foot its utmost 
length 13 1/4 inches its breadth 2 1/8 the diameter of the hole 1/4 of an inch 
the Angle wth ye Rays tending towards the midle of the Image made with 
those lynes in which they would haue proceeded without refraction was 44 
degrees 56 1/2 And the vertical Angle of the Prisme 63 degr 12 Alsoe the 
refractions both sides the Prisme, that is, of the incident & emergent 
Rays, where as neere as I could make them equal and consequently about
